Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Towards Interactive Simulation of Giga-Scale Agent-Based Models on Graphics Processing Units

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research investigates techniques for efficient simulation of large scale agent-based models (ABMs). ABMs are increasingly being used to understand complex multi-scale behaviors in many natural, built and social systems. Although ABMs have the necessary structure to capture complex model characteristics in these systems, this very structure makes them computationally challenging. Current techniques for desktop computing and extensions to traditional high performance computing are incapable of efficiently handling this computational complexity. This has severely limited the applicability of ABMs. This research investigates novel techniques designed to leverage the massive computing power available on commodity graphics processing units (GPUs). It greatly expands the availability and applicability of agent-based modeling by effectively democratizing super computing for ABM simulation. Furthermore, it enables virtual testing of "what-if" scenarios in public policy, contingency planning for disaster relief, drug therapy design etc., on inexpensive desktop computers at realistic levels of detail.

The main challenge in this research is the re-formulation of ABM computation tofit the data-parallel model of GPUs. Specific research topics include representation of agent data, functions for agent motion, replication, decimation, communication, representation and manipulation of non-spatial agent networks, adaptive behaviors, run-time user interaction, fast visualization, hardware and model-aware automatic code optimization, and multi-level parallelism for multi-GPU platforms. The techniques developed are being applied to two specific problems in medicine: simulation of tuberculosis and systemic inflammatory response syndrome. These models enable efficient simulation of disease pathology and in-silico testing of novel therapeutic drug protocols. Educational topics include development of courses, outreach to K-12 students through development of ABM themed video games, undergraduate involvement in research, and the development of a comprehensive dissemination web page.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant investigated data-parallel algorithms for accelerating the simulation of agent-based models (ABMS) on commodity graphics processing units (GPUs). The ABM technique is a bottom up method of simulating complex discrete dynamic systems. Independent autonomous entities called agents interact with each other at a local level based on certain rules. The macro-level behavior of the system emerges from these local interactions. Due to the emergent nature of ABMs, model sizes have to be representative of the real system and therefore are intractable on traditional CPU-based computing.  GPUs on the other hand have much higher computing power and memory bandwidth but use the restrictive data-parallel computing model. This research developed novel algorithms to enable the simulation of large scale ABMs on GPUs. Novel techniques were developed to handle agent motion, agent communication, birth and death, and the computation of statisctical measures. The efficacy of these new algortihms was demostrated by accelerating prototype models such as Sugarscape and Stupid Bugs. Furthermore, these algorithms were also used to accelerate models of ABMs of Tuberculosis, the human immune system, chemical kinetics, and ecology. Depend on the complexity of the models, a 10x-100x speed up was achieved as compared to a traditional CPU-based serial computing framework. 

This work has greatly increased the accessibility and availability of ABM modeling to researchers in a variety of fields such as ecology, computational biology, immunology, and economics. This research has demonstrated that realistically sized ABMs can be run on off-the-shelf desktop hardware. 

This grant provided research opportunities for several graduate and undergraduate students. They were trained in the state-of-the-art methods for parallel computing using GPUs and ABM techniques for simulating complex dynamic systems. Several of these students were able to attend conferences and present the finding and participated in the writing of manuscripts for publication in archival journals. The grant enabled the PI to establish a research program in high performance comuting and complex system simulation. A new course in high performance data-parallel computing on GPUs was also developed.
